articles.headline: Judge Puts Settlement on Katrina in Question
articles.snippet: A federal judge in Mississippi has rejected a settlement by State Farm Insurance that was expected to provide several hundred million dollars to help policyholders rebuild homes destroyed by the storm.
articles.abstract: A federal judge in Mississippi has rejected a settlement by State Farm Insurance that was expected to provide several hundred million dollars to help policyholders rebuild homes destroyed by the storm.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Mississippi, citing the need for more information, has rejected  at least temporarily  a settlement by State Farm Insurance that was expected to provide several hundred million dollars to help policyholders rebuild homes destroyed by Hurricane Katrina 17 months ago.

articles.headline: The Dangers of Swinging for the Fences
articles.snippet: That era when Pfizer was the king of the hill wasn’t some distant age — it was just maybe three or four years ago. Oh, how the mighty have fallen!
articles.abstract: That era when Pfizer was the king of the hill wasn’t some distant age — it was just maybe three or four years ago. Oh, how the mighty have fallen!
articles.lead_paragraph: There was once a pharmaceutical company that could do no wrong. It had the best-selling drug in the world. It saturated the airwaves with its ads, and swarmed doctors’ offices with its army of good-looking sales representatives. It had mastered the art of turning drugs into blockbusters. It made many billions in profits. Wall Street analysts loved it.

articles.headline: Tokyo Cuts Aid, and Hinterland Withers in Japan
articles.snippet: How closely will Tokyo hew to its new policy of weaning rural Japan from the central government?
articles.abstract: How closely will Tokyo hew to its new policy of weaning rural Japan from the central government?
articles.lead_paragraph: YUBARI, Japan  Buried in chest-deep snow, History Village sprawled across a valley here, undisturbed by the tourists it was supposed to attract.

articles.headline: Turning 60, and Doing So With 1,500
articles.snippet: The guest list is a closely guarded secret, but appears to be deep and wide. The man of the hour is Stephen A. Schwarzman, the hedge fund titan.
articles.abstract: The guest list is a closely guarded secret, but appears to be deep and wide. The man of the hour is Stephen A. Schwarzman, the hedge fund titan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not every Wall Street titan can celebrate his birthday in a place that holds 1,500 people. Unless, of course, that titan is Stephen A. Schwarzman, who is on the verge of clinching the biggest buyout deal ever.

articles.headline: Offering Help for Former Foster Care Youths
articles.snippet: Many states are expanding their efforts to help young adults in foster care prepare for life outside the system.
articles.abstract: Many states are expanding their efforts to help young adults in foster care prepare for life outside the system.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — When current and former foster children formed a group to help youths who had turned 18 and were “aging out” of the system, one of the first things they did was hold a luggage drive.

articles.headline: Intel Says Chips Will Run Faster, Using Less Power
articles.snippet: Intel has overhauled the basic building block of the information age, paving the way for faster and more energy-efficient processors.
articles.abstract: Intel has overhauled the basic building block of the information age, paving the way for faster and more energy-efficient processors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Intel, the world’s largest chip maker, has overhauled the basic building block of the information age, paving the way for a new generation of faster and more energy-efficient processors.

articles.headline: Gap Is in Need of a Niche
articles.snippet: In an era of niches, when exclusion is as vital as inclusion, Gap has become an anachronism: a single chain, selling only its own brand.
articles.abstract: In an era of niches, when exclusion is as vital as inclusion, Gap has become an anachronism: a single chain, selling only its own brand.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2004, Gap put on a splashy ad campaign called, “How do you wear it?” with Lenny Kravtiz and Sarah Jessica Parker. It featured the pair dancing in customized Gap jeans — his with metal studs down the seam; hers with a waist-to-cuff velvet ribbon.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Hillary Chura

articles.headline: Giuliani Is Cautious as He Weighs ’08 Decision
articles.snippet: Even as other Republicans have all but formally declared their candidacies, Rudolph W. Giuliani has proceeded more cautiously.
articles.abstract: Even as other Republicans have all but formally declared their candidacies, Rudolph W. Giuliani has proceeded more cautiously.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani, who developed a national reputation for decisive and reassuring leadership after 9/11, now faces the odd challenge of having to reassure some supporters that he can be decisive about a very different issue: running for president.

articles.headline: A Contrarian View: Save Less and Still Retire With Enough
articles.snippet: Some economists say that Americans could be saving less — and spending more — while they are younger.
articles.abstract: Some economists say that Americans could be saving less — and spending more — while they are younger.
articles.lead_paragraph: Could it be possible that you are saving too much for your retirement?

articles.headline: Is the Fix Worse Than the Problem?
articles.snippet: Past attempts to shrink executive pay have caused it to climb.
articles.abstract: Past attempts to shrink executive pay have caused it to climb.
articles.lead_paragraph: CONGRESS has a new idea about how to rein in executive pay. Trouble is, the plan will squeeze midlevel workers, even as they need to save more money for retirement. And it won’t even dent top executives’ takes.

articles.headline: In Law School, Obama Found Political Voice
articles.snippet: Barack Obama arrived at Harvard as an unknown; by the time he left, he had become a political sensation.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama arrived at Harvard as an unknown; by the time he left, he had become a political sensation.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 23 — The peers who elected Barack Obama as the first black president of the Harvard Law Review say he was a natural leader, an impressive student, a nice guy. But in the 1990 Revue — the graduating editors’ gleeful parody of their elite publication — they said quite a bit more.

articles.headline: Saudi Officials Seek to Temper the Price of Oil
articles.snippet: Saudi Arabia has signaled  that it is committed to keeping oil at around $50 a barrel — down $27 a barrel from its summer peak.
articles.abstract: Saudi Arabia has signaled  that it is committed to keeping oil at around $50 a barrel — down $27 a barrel from its summer peak.
articles.lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia, which benefited immensely from record oil prices last year, has sent signals in the past two weeks that it is committed to keeping oil at around $50 a barrel — down $27 a barrel from the summer peak that shook consumers across the developed world.

articles.headline: On Iran, Bush Faces Haunting Echoes of Iraq
articles.snippet: As the president and his aides calibrate how directly to confront Iran, they insist that  their warnings are not a prelude to war.
articles.abstract: As the president and his aides calibrate how directly to confront Iran, they insist that  their warnings are not a prelude to war.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 — As President Bush and his aides calibrate how directly to confront Iran, they are discovering that both their words and their strategy are haunted by the echoes of four years ago — when their warnings of terrorist activity and nuclear ambitions were clearly a prelude to war.

articles.headline: Preaching From the Ballmer Pulpit
articles.snippet: Can Microsoft thrive in a new digital era? In the worldview of Steven A. Ballmer, the company’s chief executive,  failure is not an option.
articles.abstract: Can Microsoft thrive in a new digital era? In the worldview of Steven A. Ballmer, the company’s chief executive,  failure is not an option.
articles.lead_paragraph: RUNNING a storied enterprise like Microsoft — software heavyweight, geyser of cash, corporate icon — is about much more than energy and commitment, says Steven A. Ballmer, the company’s chief executive. It is all but a calling, an article of faith.

articles.headline: Women Feeling Freer to Suggest ‘Vote for Mom’
articles.snippet: The new politics of maternity strike down the notion that women have to play down their softer, domestic sides.
articles.abstract: The new politics of maternity strike down the notion that women have to play down their softer, domestic sides.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 — Some women were struck by the politics of maternity practiced by Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in recent weeks, the imagery and stagecraft that highlighted their roles as mothers and/or grandmothers.

articles.headline: ‘Dreamgirls’ Banked on Best Picture, and Lost
articles.snippet: “Dreamgirls” may well be remembered as the picture that showed how far a studio cannot go in seeking a prize.
articles.abstract: “Dreamgirls” may well be remembered as the picture that showed how far a studio cannot go in seeking a prize.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 — Oscar theorists all have their notions about the failure of “Dreamgirls” to get a best picture nomination last week, despite eight other nominations for Academy Awards and an all-out drive by its backers for top honors.

articles.headline: At Davos, the Squabble Resumes on How to Wire the Third World
articles.snippet: Passions still run high at the World Economic Forum over the best way to deploy computers in the developing world.
articles.abstract: Passions still run high at the World Economic Forum over the best way to deploy computers in the developing world.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 28 — Here in the Swiss mountains at the World Economic Forum, the annual conclave of world leaders, concerns over a growing digital divide this year have taken a back seat to the challenge of climate change.

articles.headline: Feeding Frenzy for a Big Story, Even if It’s False
articles.snippet: The first anonymous smear of the 2008 presidential race illustrated how easily dubious information can spread.
articles.abstract: The first anonymous smear of the 2008 presidential race illustrated how easily dubious information can spread.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  Jeffrey T. Kuhner, whose Web site published the first anonymous smear of the 2008 presidential race, is hardly the only editor who will not reveal his reporters’ sources. What sets him apart is that he will not even disclose the names of his reporters.

articles.headline: Levi’s Turns to Suing Its Rivals
articles.snippet: The design for a Levi’s pocket, first used 133 years ago, has become the biggest legal battleground in U.S. fashion.
articles.abstract: The design for a Levi’s pocket, first used 133 years ago, has become the biggest legal battleground in U.S. fashion.
articles.lead_paragraph: United States Patent and Trademark No. 1,139,254 is not much to look at: a pentagon surrounding a childlike drawing of a seagull in flight.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Iranian Reveals Plan to Expand Role in Iraq
articles.snippet: Iran’s ambassador to Baghdad outlined a plan to expand its economic and military ties with Iraq that will almost certainly bring more conflict with the U.S.
articles.abstract: Iran’s ambassador to Baghdad outlined a plan to expand its economic and military ties with Iraq that will almost certainly bring more conflict with the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Jan. 28 — Iran’s ambassador to Baghdad outlined an ambitious plan on Sunday to greatly expand its economic and military ties with Iraq — including an Iranian national bank branch in the heart of the capital — just as the Bush administration has been warning the Iranians to stop meddling in Iraqi affairs.

articles.headline: 250 Are Killed in Major Iraq Battle
articles.snippet: An American helicopter was shot down in fighting near Najaf between gunmen and Iraqi forces backed by U.S. firepower.
articles.abstract: An American helicopter was shot down in fighting near Najaf between gunmen and Iraqi forces backed by U.S. firepower.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Jan. 28 — At least 250 militants were killed and an American helicopter was shot down in violent clashes near the southern city of Najaf on Sunday, Iraqi officials said.

articles.headline: Tech Barons Take on New Project: Energy Policy
articles.snippet: Technology investors are on a crusade to influence energy policy because they have a big stake in the outcome.
articles.abstract: Technology investors are on a crusade to influence energy policy because they have a big stake in the outcome.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 28 — President Bush set broad goals last week for the adoption of alternative energy. Hoping to take on the role of filling in the details is an unlikely group: Silicon Valley’s technology investors.

articles.headline: At Last, Television Ratings Go to College
articles.snippet: Nielsen Media Research will include the viewing of students living away from home in its count for the first time.
articles.abstract: Nielsen Media Research will include the viewing of students living away from home in its count for the first time.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, Nielsen Media Research has affixed the same value to every college student watching television while away at school: zero. As a result, industry executives have complained for years that shows appealing to a younger audience have been underrated.

articles.headline: Citigroup and CNBC Cozy Up
articles.snippet: Why was Maria Bartiromo making appearances at the request of Citigroup — and other companies — that sit dead center in her beat as a host on CNBC?
articles.abstract: Why was Maria Bartiromo making appearances at the request of Citigroup — and other companies — that sit dead center in her beat as a host on CNBC?
articles.lead_paragraph: Commerce runs on the favor bank. That is simply how things work when the body shop owner notices that your car is running a little loud and sends you to his pal Ricky the muffler guy, or when big drug companies play nice with friendly doctors. When it comes to business, it’s a natural reflex to favor those who favor us.
